entry.emph: Summary judgment on plaintiff's application — Rule 13.1

row.entry: This rule sets out the circumstances in which a plaintiff can obtain judgment on a claim without proceeding to a contested final hearing of the ordinary kind. The rule requires the plaintiff to satisfy the court that there is no real defence to the claim, or only a defence as to its amount.

entry.emph: Summary dismissal on defendant's application — Rule 13.4

row.entry: This rule sets out the circumstances in which a defendant can have proceedings dismissed without a contested final hearing of the ordinary kind. It applies to proceedings that do not disclose a cause of action, proceedings that are an abuse of process and proceedings that are vexatious.
This Part does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.

The rules in this Part substantially repeat the former SCR Part 13, DCR Part 11A and LCR PartÂ 10A. The power in relation to vexatious proceedings is expressed as a power to dismiss, rather than as an alternative power to stay or dismiss.
Appeal against an order for summary judgment ‥ [13.1.15]
Application to strike out pleadings and contents of documents ‥ [13.4.25]
Continuation of proceedings after partial judgment or dismissal ‥ [r 13.3] , [r 13.5]
Defects curable by amendment of pleadings ‥ [13.4.35]
Discretion to dismiss proceedings — absence of reasonable cause of action ‥ [13.4.15]
Discretion to refuse summary judgment — Contracts Review Act defence ‥ [13.1.40]
Evidence in support of dismissal application ‥ [r 13.1(1)] –[r 13.4(2)]
Evidence in support of summary judgment application ‥ [r 13.1(a)] –[r 13.1(b)]
Evidence of the facts upon which the claim is based ‥ [13.1.45]
General principles governing summary disposal of proceedings ‥ [13.1.5]
Part of claim — no defence to ‥ [13.1.55]
Questions of law determinable on summary application ‥ [13.1.65]
Stay of judgment, pending cross claim ‥ [r 13.2]
Stay where claim asserted against a third party ‥ [13.2.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 13.1] r 13.1 Summary judgment (cf SCR Part 13, rule 2; DCR Part 11A, rule 2; LCR Part 10A, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Summary judgment (cf SCR Part 13, rule 2; DCR Part 11A, rule 2; LCR Part 10A, rule 2)

p.text: If, on application by the plaintiff in relation to the plaintiff’s claim for relief or any part of the plaintiff’s claim for relief:
there is evidence of the facts on which the claim or part of the claim is based, and

there is evidence, given by the plaintiff or by some responsible person, that, in the belief of the person giving the evidence, the defendant has no defence to the claim or part of the claim, or no defence except as to the amount of any damages claimed,
the court may give such judgment for the plaintiff, or make such order on the claim or that part of the claim, as the case requires.
Without limiting subrule (1), the court may give judgment for the plaintiff for damages to be assessed.
In this rule, a reference to damages includes a reference to the value of goods.

level.toc-caption: [13.1.5] General principles governing summary disposal of proceedings

heading.title: General principles governing summary disposal of proceedings

p.text: A party will not be denied a contested merits hearing unless the absence of a cause of action or defence is clearly demonstrated: General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125 at 129; [1965] ALR 636; BC6400590Â . Consequently no court should determine proceedings summarily if there is a real question in dispute: Dey v Victorian Railway Cmrs (1949) 78 CLR 62 at 91; [1949] ALR 333; BC4900050Â . The criterion for satisfaction that there is no real question in dispute has been variously described — as one where the allegedly contentious matter is (i) “so obviously untenable that it cannot possibly succeed”, “manifestly groundless”, “so manifestly faulty that it does not admit of argument”, (ii) one which “the court is satisfied cannot succeed”, (iii) one where “under no possibility can there be a good cause of action”, or (iv) one which “would involve useless expense”: General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW), above, CLR at 129Â ; Spencer vÂ Commonwealth (2010) 241 CLR 118; 269 ALR 233; [2010] HCA 28; BC201006309 atÂ [24]Â (must be clear that there is no real question); Pannizutti v Trask (1987) 10 NSWLR 531 at 536Â ; Rajski v Powell (1987) 11 NSWLR 522 at 524Â ; Wentworth v Rogers (No 5) (1986) 6 NSWLR 534Â ; Brimson v Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 937 at 942Â .

All of these expressions point to the requirement of a high degree of certainty before a party is deprived of the opportunity to have their claim determined in the usual way: Agar v Hyde (2000) 201 CLR 552; 173 ALR 665; [2000] HCA 41; BC200004311 at [57]Â ; Shaw vÂ NSW [2012] NSWCA 102; BC201202352 atÂ [30]–[33]Â (high degree of certainty required to strike out a cause of action as groundless). This requirement is “demanding”: Air Services Australia v Zarb (NSWCA, Priestley, Powell JJA and Rolfe AJA, CA 40570/97, 26 August 1998, unreported, BC9804215). It has been described as requiring “exceptional caution”, and a “high degree of certainty about the ultimate outcome of proceedings”: Webster v Lampard (1993) 177 CLR 598; 116 ALR 545; [1993] HCA 57; BC9303614Â (exceptional caution required where untested evidence is not inherently incredible); Spencer v Commonwealth (2010) 241 CLR 118; 269 ALR 233; [2010] HCA 28; BC201006309Â atÂ [24]–[25] (no summary dismissal of a claim that statutory restrictions on land clearing involved Commonwealth acquisitions on unjust terms). As to the distinction between arguable and merely complex, but untenable, claims see [13.4.30] .

Summary disposal is inappropriate where there is any serious conflict as to any matter of fact: Sidebottom v Cureton (1937) 54 WN (NSW) 88Â ; and where there is any other reason why the applicant for summary disposal fails to discharge the onus of showing that there is no possibility of the defence succeeding: Bayne v Baillieu (1908) 6 CLR 382 at 396–7; 14 ALR 426Â ; Wardley Australia Ltd v Western Australia (1992) 175 CLR 514 at 533, 558; 109 ALR 247; BC9202700Â (limitation questions should not be decided in interlocutory proceedings except in the clearest of cases). See generally Spellson v George (1992) 26 NSWLR 666 at 678–9Â (possibility of evidence emerging in the defendant’s case). These general principles are often summarised in the proposition that summary judgment is not appropriate if the defence raises a triable issue: Jacobs v Booth’s Distillery Co (1901) 85 LT 262Â ; Cloverdell Lumber Co Pty Ltd v Abbott (1924) 34 CLR 122 at 133; 30 ALR 109 at 113Â . This includes an issue that is likely to turn on questions of credit and applies even where the court may have a strong preliminary view as to the probable result: Bank of New South Wales v Murray [1963] NSWR 515; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 1289Â . Triable issues are not, however, confined to issues of fact. The existence of a fairly arguable question of construction may warrant the refusal of summary judgment: Shurmur v Young (1889) 5 TLR 155; cf Bowes v Caustic Soda & Chlorine Syndicate (1893) 9 TLR 328Â ; and see also General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125 at 130; [1965] ALR 636; BC6400590Â ; Williams and Humbert Ltd v W & H Trade Marks (Jersey) Ltd [1986] AC 368; 1 All ER 129Â . A mere denial of the plaintiff’s claim or a mere assertion of some matter, such as fraud, which is alleged to defeat the plaintiff’s claim will not be sufficient to defeat an application if a plaintiff has otherwise made out an entitlement to an order of summary judgment: Wallingford v Mutual Society (1880) LR 5 App Cas 685 at 695, 705; Re General Railway Syndicate [1900] 1 Ch 365 at 369Â ; Moscow Narodny Bank v Mosbert Finance (Aust) Pty Ltd [1976] WAR 109Â but see Codd v Delap (1905) 92 LT 510Â . Furthermore, even if the defendant provides evidence which tends to show the existence of a triable issue, it is open to the plaintiff to show that on the whole of the evidence there is really no substance in the defence sought to be established: Gemeinwirtschaft v City of London Garages Ltd [1971] 1 All ER 541Â (an action on a bill of exchange).

level.toc-caption: [13.1.15] Appeal against an order for summary judgment

heading.title: Appeal against an order for summary judgment

p.text: An order granting a plaintiff’s application for summary judgment is a final order and attracts a right of appeal: King Investment Solutions Pty Ltd v Hussain [2005] NSWSC 1076; BC200509160Â citing Thomson v DCT (VCA, 16 June 2000, unreported); Hunt v Knabe (No 2) (1992) 8 WAR 96Â ; contra Schiffer v Pattison (2005) 143 FCR 328; 215 ALR 505; [2005] FCA 494; BC200502315Â . An order granting or dismissing an application for summary dismissal is an interlocutory order, and requires leave to appeal: Wickstead v Browne (1992) 30 NSWLR 1 at 11Â ; Hall v Nominal Defendant (1966) 117 CLR 423 at 440; [1966] ALR 705; BC6600070Â . But since the practical effect of such an order is the final determination of the rights of the parties, leave to appeal may more readily be given: Garrard (t/as Arthur Anderson & Co) v Email Furniture Pty Ltd (1993) 32 NSWLR 662 at 665Â ; Itek Graphix Pty Ltd v Elliott (2002) 54 NSWLR 207 at [154]–[165]; [2002] NSWCA 104; BC200201727Â ; see further [SCA sÂ 101.60] .

It is generally essential that the plaintiff, or some responsible person, deposes to a belief that the defendant has no defence to the claim or part (General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125 at 129; [1965] ALR 636; BC6400590Â ; Muntz v Elkington (1891) 17 VLR 23Â ; Harry Smith Car Sales Pty Ltd v Claycom Vegetable Supply Co Pty Ltd (1978) 29 ACTR 21Â ) or alternatively, depose to a belief that the defence is limited to the question of damages: Dummer v Brown [1953] 1 QB 710Â . However, if the court is in fact satisfied that there is no defence to the claim, a technical non-compliance with the rule will not necessarily justify refusal of the application: Long Leys Co Pty Ltd v Silkdale Pty Ltd (1991) 5 BPR 11,512Â . The term “responsible person” may include a solicitor or their clerk: Hallett v Andrews (1898) 42 Sol Jo 68 or an employee of the plaintiff — at least where the person has personal knowledge of the facts: Pathe Freres Cinema Ltd v United Electric Theatres Ltd [1914] 3 KB 1253 at 1255Â .

Before deposing to a belief that there is no defence, the deponent should take care to consider the precise claim pleaded and ensure that the evidence which is adduced in support of the application supports that precise claim: Hawker Noyes Equipment Pty Ltd v Dueeasy Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Meagher, Sheller, Cole JJA, 9 July 1996, unreported, BC9603049). It may sometimes happen that a defendant may have a prima facie defence to the claim pleaded in the statement of claim — subject to any reply by the plaintiff. If the deponent’s belief is ultimately based upon a matter that arises only in reply, there is authority to suggest that the summary judgment procedure may not be appropriate: Harry Smith Car Sales Pty Ltd v Claycom Vegetable Supply Co Pty Ltd , above.

A triable issue is one about which there is a genuinely arguable contest. If the issue involves complex factual matters, there is an increased probability that its contest is arguable and gives rise to a triable issue. But it is also possible that the apparent arguability to which the complexity gives rise is more apprehended that real. The cases recognise that the mere fact that a transaction or argument is complex, and may involve extensive argument, does not mean that a court is required to refuse a summary judgment application on that ground alone: Dey v Victorian Railway Cmrs (1949) 78 CLR 62 at 91; [1949] ALR 333; BC4900050Â ; General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125 at 129; [1965] ALR 636; BC6400590Â (extensive argument may be necessary to determine that a claim or defence is so untenable that it cannot succeed); Silverton Ltd v Harvey [1975] 1 NSWLR 659 at 665Â .

It is only in exceptional cases that the court will make a declaration on an application for summary judgment: GPI Leisure Corp Ltd v Yuill (NSWSC, YoungÂ J, No 1907/94, 6 August 1997, unreported, BC9704052 at [12]) .

The court has a general discretion as to the circumstances in which an order for summary judgment will be appropriate and always retains a discretion to refuse to make such an order: Wallingford v Mutual Society (1880) LR 5 App Cas 685; Baulderstone Hornibrook Pty Ltd v HBO & DC Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 821; BC200105624Â (Commercial List proceedings — issues more appropriately dealt with at final hearing). In Miles v Bull [1969] 1 QB 258Â , Megarry J gave leave to defend where the defendant asserted that the documents upon which the plaintiff’s case was based were shams. An allegation that material facts may arise before the trial would normally take place may defeat an application for summary judgment: see Brisbane City Council v Southern Electricity Authority of Queensland (1968) 15 LGRA 230; 42 ALJR 78Â (where the defendant had an application pending to an industrial tribunal to reduce the amount for the electricity charges which were the subject of the action). A mere claim to be entitled to test the plaintiff’s case by cross-examination would not ordinarily be sufficient (Rosser v Austral Wine and Spirit Co Pty Ltd [1980] VR 313Â ), although it may be, for example, where the plaintiff’s claim is against a deceased estate and the only evidence available is the uncorroborated evidence of the plaintiff: Harrison v Bottenheim (1878) 26 WR 362Â ; Crump v Cavendish (1880) 5 Ex D 211 at 214Â . Delay in making the application is not ordinarily a sufficient basis to refuse an application for summary judgment: Brinks Ltd v Abu-Saleh [1995] 4 All ER 65; [1995] 1 WLR 1478Â .

level.toc-caption: [13.1.40] Discretion to refuse summary judgment — Contracts Review Act defence

heading.title: Discretion to refuse summary judgment — Contracts Review Act defence

p.text: Where the defence involves a claim under the Contracts Review Act, a motion for summary judgment will usually be inappropriate: Commercial Banking Co of Sydney Ltd v Pollard [1983] 1 NSWLR 74Â . But summary judgment may be ordered in such a case if there is no prima facie evidence to support the claim for relief under the Act (Hogan v Howard Finance Ltd (1987) ASC Â¶55-594), and the mere fact that a party to a contract can point to circumstances which fall within the words of one or more paragraphs in s 9(2) of the Act does not mean that there is an arguable case for such relief: Anderson v Yacoub (NSWSC, Newman J, No 11080/91, 15 October 1992, unreported, BC9201551); Cogo v Permanent Custodians (NSWSC, Cohen J, 23 September 1992, unreported); National Australia Bank Ltd v Winskill (NSWSC, Wood J, 21 June 1994, unreported); Permanent Trustee Australia Ltd v Biviano (NSWSC, Sperling J, 23 February 1996, unreported, BC9600253).

level.toc-caption: [13.1.45] Evidence of the facts upon which the claim is based

heading.title: Evidence of the facts upon which the claim is based

p.text: The rule requires evidence of the facts on which the claim is based. It is not sufficient merely to verify the allegations in the statement of claim — except perhaps in a simple action in debt, for example, where it may be sufficient for the deponent of a supporting affidavit to say that the defendant is indebted to the plaintiff in the sum of $x for goods sold and delivered the particulars of which appear in the statement of claim: see May v Chidley [1894] 1 QB 451Â and Roberts v Plant [1895] 1 QB 597Â . If the plaintiff’s claim relies upon documents, then those necessary to prove the claim should be put in evidence — especially since the modern system of pleading merely requires that their effect be set out in the pleadings: Suburban Homes Pty Ltd v Ward [1928] VLR 267Â ; Australia & New Zealand Bank Ltd v Maile [1965] QWN 28Â . It is not necessary to prove every particular of the statement of claim provided the essential elements of the cause of action are established: Symon & Co v Palmers Stores (1903) Ltd [1912] 1 KB 259 at 267; Evans Deakin & Co Pty Ltd v Kayser Engineers and Constructors Inc [1968] Qd R 379 at 382Â . The plaintiff may provide the evidence necessary by affidavits of a number of different deponents: Rourke v Victorian Finance Guarantee and Share Co Ltd (1894) 20 VLR 8Â ; Les Fils Dreyfus v Clarke [1958] 1 All ER 459; [1958] 1 WLR 300Â .

Consistent with the general principles outlined in [13.1.5], the party seeking judgment under this rule bears the onus of satisfying the court that there is no real question to be tried: Singh v Varinder Kaur (1985) 61 ALR 720 at 722Â ; Rushcutters Investments Pty Ltd v Grellman (NSWCA, Full Court, 17 June 1987, unreported, BC8701311); Hawker Noyes Equipment Pty Ltd v Dueeasy Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Meagher, Sheller, Cole JJA, 9 July 1996, unreported, BC9603049). The fact that the applicant carries the onus means that the defendant does not have to affirmatively establish the defence: Gemeinwirtschaft v City of London Garages Ltd [1971] 1 All ER 541Â ; Sunbird Plaza Pty Ltd v Aurisch Investments Pty Ltd (No 2) [1983] 2 Qd R 383Â ; Langdale v Danby [1982] 1 WLR 1123; [1982] 3 All ER 129Â ; cf Barton v Moseley (1964) 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 417; (1965) 65 SR (NSW) 412Â (which deal with the procedure under the Common Law Procedure Act); Fancourt v Mercantile Credits Ltd (1983) 154 CLR 87; 48 ALR 1 at 10Â ; Clarke v Union Bank of Australia Ltd (1917) 23 CLR 5; [1917] VLR 284Â ; Jones v Stone [1984] AC 122; Evans v Bartlam [1937] AC 473; [1937] 2 All ER 646Â ; European Asian Bank AG v Punjab and Sind Bank (No 2) [1983] 1 WLR 642 at 654Â . Even if it appears to the court that the defence would not be made out on the basis of the evidence before it on the hearing of the application, it may nevertheless remain open to the court to allow for the possibility that discovery, interrogatories and the issue of subpoenas may enable a defence to be established at the trial and therefore refuse the application: Peter Kent Development Pty Ltd v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 6 May 1980, unreported); Hogan v Howard Finance Ltd (1987) ASC Â¶55-594.

level.toc-caption: [13.1.55] Part of claim — no defence to

heading.title: Part of claim — no defence to

p.text: The qualification contained in r 13.1(1)(b) (ie, no defence except as to the amount of any damages) implies the possibility of obtaining summary judgment in relation to part of a claim: Costain Australia Ltd v State Superannuation Board (NSWSC, Brownie J, 22 February 1991, unreported, BC9102319) (builder recovers summary judgment for the balance of a claim and interest after allowing for claimed rectification costs and damages).
Legislation cited in [13.1.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 3.

The expression “plaintiff” is defined in CPA s 3 to include a cross-claimant. It follows from the definition that any claimant party in the proceedings, whether under the original initiating process or under a cross-claim, has a separate entitlement to resort to the summary judgment procedure. Even where the plaintiff’s claim relies upon allegations of fraud, a cross-claimant may still move for summary judgment: Australian & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Cameron (NSWSC, Mathews J, No 14720/90, 20 December 1990, unreported, BC9001831) (summary judgment given for possession of land notwithstanding fraud defence).

level.toc-caption: [13.1.65] Questions of law determinable on summary application

heading.title: Questions of law determinable on summary application

p.text: The existence of a difficult question of law is not an insuperable barrier to the grant of summary judgment: see Wickstead v Browne (1992) 30 NSWLR 1Â and Esanda Finance Corp Ltd v Peat Marwick Hungerfords (1997) 188 CLR 241; 142 ALR 750; [1997] HCA 8Â . The court may decide questions of law on the application if it forms the view that it is appropriate to do so: Silverton Ltd v Harvey [1975] 1 NSWLR 659 at 665Â ; Goddard v Polar Cream Pty Ltd (1946) 47 SR (NSW) 154Â ; Sunbird Plaza Pty Ltd v Boheto Pty Ltd [1983] 1 Qd R 248Â . But the more complex the question of law that is involved, the more likely it is that its resolution will depend on disputed issues of fact, and thus be unsuitable for summary determination: NRMA Insurance Ltd v AW Edwards (1995) 11 BCL 200; BC9403282Â .
Legislation cited in [13.1.70] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 86.

The rule permits the court to make such order as the case requires. This permission, when read with CPA s 86 , allows an order for summary judgment to be made on terms. It also permits conditional orders to be made. Consequently, it is permissible to make an order that the plaintiff have summary judgment unless the defendant pays into court the whole or part of the moneys claimed. Such an order may be appropriate where there is reason to doubt that the defence has been set up in good faith. But such an order generally ought not be made if compliance with it would be likely to preclude the defendant from properly contesting an otherwise apparently arguable claim: Fieldrank Ltd v Stein [1961] 3 All ER 681 at 683; [1961] 1 WLR 1287 at 1289Â and see Jacobs v Booth’s Distillery Co (1901) 85 LT 262Â and Ionian Bank Ltd v Couvreur [1969] 2 All ER 651; [1969] 1 WLR 781Â . But no requirement for payment into court should be made where compliance would impose such an impossible financial burden on the defendant as to prevent it from defending the claim: MV Yorke Motors v Edwards [1982] 1 All ER 1024; [1982] 1 WLR 444Â . Similarly, if summary judgment is given to only part of the claim, it is not proper to impose a condition that defendant pay the summary judgment amount before being allowed to defend the residue of the claim: Dennis v Seymour (1879) 4 Ex D 80; cf Cloverdell Lumber Co Pty Ltd v Abbott (1924) 34 CLR 122; 30 ALR 109Â and Carta Para Goldmining Co Ltd v Fastnedge (1882) 30 WR 880. A payment into court creates a charge on the moneys in favour of the plaintiff, but this charge may be void as a preference under bankruptcy laws: Commercial Banking Co of Sydney Ltd v Colonial Financiers of Australia Pty Ltd [1972] VR 702Â .
Legislation cited in [13.1.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.3(2).

An application for summary judgment may be made under the present rule before any defence is filed and even before the expiry of the time for the filing of a defence. In such a case the court may fix the time for filing the defence, on the hearing of the motion: r 14.3(2) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 13.2] r 13.2 Stay of judgment pending determination of cross-claim (cf SCR Part 13, rule 3; DCR Part 11A, rule 2A)

leg:heading.title: Stay of judgment pending determination of cross-claim (cf SCR Part 13, rule 3; DCR Part 11A, rule 2A)

p.text: If the court gives judgment against a party under rule 13.1 , and that party has made a cross-claim against the party obtaining the judgment, the court may stay enforcement of the judgment until determination of the cross-claim.

A plaintiff who is entitled to summary judgment on the original claim may obtain an order for summary judgment notwithstanding that triable issues arise in the cross-claim proceedings. In such cases, although summary judgment will be ordered, it will often occur that execution on the judgment will be stayed — especially if there is a practical connection between the claim and the cross-claim: Sheppards & Co v Wilkinson & Jarvis (1889) 6 TLR 13Â . Thus in Slater v Cathcart (1891) 8 TLR 92Â , where a solicitor claimed for costs and there was a cross-claim in negligence, payment into court of the costs was ordered with a stay pending the hearing of the cross-claim. But where a plaintiff sues on a cheque or bill of exchange and applies for summary judgment, the defendant will rarely be entitled to a stay for the purpose of asserting a cross-claim: Nova (Jersey) Knit Ltd v Kammgarn Spinnerei GmbH [1977] 2 All ER 463; [1977] 1 WLR 713Â ; Esso Petroleum Co Ltd v Milton [1997] 2 All ER 593Â (claim for payment under a direct debit arrangement).

level.toc-caption: [13.2.10] Stay where claim asserted against a third party

heading.title: Stay where claim asserted against a third party

p.text: Although the rule only deals with the grant of a stay where there are cross-claims between the plaintiff and defendant, it is clear that the court’s powers to grant a stay of execution of the judgment are not confined to that situation. If the judgment debtor has a bona fide claim against a third person, and success on that claim would entitle the defendant to a complete indemnity in relation to the judgment, that circumstance may afford a proper basis for the grant of a stay, irrespective of whether or not the claim has been brought by cross-claim or in separate proceedings: State Bank of Victoria v Parry [1989] WAR 240Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 13.3] r 13.3 Continuation of proceedings following partial judgment (cf SCR Part 13, rule 6; DCR Part 11A, rule 4; LCR Part 10A, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Continuation of proceedings following partial judgment (cf SCR Part 13, rule 6; DCR Part 11A, rule 4; LCR Part 10A, rule 4)

p.text: If, in any proceedings:
a party applies for judgment, and
the proceedings are not wholly disposed of by the judgment,
the proceedings may be continued as regards any claim or part of a claim not disposed of by the judgment.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 13.4] r 13.4 Frivolous and vexatious proceedings (cf SCR Part 13, rule 5; DCR Part 11A, rule 3; LCR Part 10A, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Frivolous and vexatious proceedings (cf SCR Part 13, rule 5; DCR Part 11A, rule 3; LCR Part 10A, rule 3)

p.text: If in any proceedings it appears to the court that in relation to the proceedings generally or in relation to any claim for relief in the proceedings:
the proceedings are frivolous or vexatious, or
no reasonable cause of action is disclosed, or
the proceedings are an abuse of the process of the court,
the court may order that the proceedings be dismissed generally or in relation to that claim.
The court may receive evidence on the hearing of an application for an order under subrule (1).
Legislation cited in [13.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ssÂ 56, 67.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 13.4, 14.28.

Abuse of process is a general concept, amenable more to illustration than definition: Batistatos v RTA of NSW (2006) 227 ALR 425; [2006] HCA 27; BC200604226 at [9] and [14]Â –[16]; Ridgeway v R (1995) 184 CLR 19 at 74–5; 129 ALR 41; BC9506420Â . The concept of abuse of process is relevant to many provisions of the CPA and UCPR — including CPA ssÂ 56 and 67 and UCPR rr 13.4 and 14.28 — and is discussed more fully in the notes to the latter rule, especially at [14.28.5] . It is sufficient to note here some of the various examples that have been held to give rise to abuse of process:
proceedings that have no real prospect of resulting in a substantial remedy and involve unjustifiable expense or use of judicial resources: see [s 60.15] .

Where proceedings have been started in one court, it may constitute an abuse of the process of the court to engage in multiple proceedings where there is a complete remedy available in the court in which the proceedings were first started: Williams v Hunt [1905] 1 KB 512Â (CA); McHenry v Lewis (1882) 22 Ch D 397Â (CA). For example, where proceedings have been commenced in a court of one state in which there is a complete remedy for defamation in respect of matter published in more than one state, it may be an abuse of process to divide the remedy by suing also in another state (Maple v David Syme & Co Ltd [1975] 1 NSWLR 97Â ) and see the observations in Meckiff v Simpson [1968] VR 62 at 63–5Â and McLean v David Syme & Co Ltd (1970) 72 SR (NSW) 513 at 528; 92 WN (NSW) 611 at 624Â (CA). Whether or not the concurrent proceedings constitute an abuse of process, and whether or not the local proceedings should be stayed, will depend upon a number of factors including the stage of the respective proceedings, the location of the subject matter, the convenience of witnesses and the likely practical effect of the order: Sterling Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd v Boots Co (Aust) Pty Ltd (1992) 34 FCR 287 at 290Â ; Hughes Motor Service Pty Ltd v Wang Computer Pty Ltd (1978) 35 FLR 346 at 351Â ; Bringmann v Lend Lease Investments Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland J, 4 December 1979, unreported); Harrison v Taree City Bowling Club Co-op Ltd (NSWSC, Needham J, 10 June 1979, unreported) (proceedings commenced in the Industrial Commission of New South Wales — injunction refused). As to the special problems that may arise in connection with proceedings concerning property in which parties to proceedings in the Family Court also have an interest see Reynolds v Reynolds [1977] 2 NSWLR 295Â ; Williams v Williams [1979] 1 NSWLR 376Â ; Foukkare v Angreb Pty Ltd [2006] NSWCA 335; BC200609700Â (respondent’s maintenance of NSWSC proceedings after resolution of FamCA proceedings constituted abuse of process).

level.toc-caption: [13.4.15] Discretion to dismiss proceedings — absence of a reasonable cause of action

p.text: Legislation cited in [13.4.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 13.1, rÂ 13.4(1)(b).
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 ssÂ 345–348.

heading.title: Discretion to dismiss proceedings — absence of a reasonable cause of action

p.text: The power to dismiss claims at an interlocutory stage of the proceedings is only appropriately exercised where the plaintiff’s claim is so clearly deficient that it would be inappropriate to allow the proceedings to continue: Cox vÂ Journeaux (NoÂ 2) (1935) 52 CLR 713 atÂ 720; 9 ALJR 127Â (“very likely” unsustainable allegations of conspiracy and fraud); see General Steel Industries Inc vÂ Commissioner for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125 atÂ 129–130; [1965] ALR 636; (1964) 38 ALJR 253; BC6400590Â (“obviously untenable”). The decided cases consistently emphasise the exceptional nature of the power, and the correspondingly restricted circumstances in which its exercise is appropriate: Co-ownership Land Development Pty Ltd vÂ Queensland Estates Pty Ltd (1973) 1 ALR 201; 47 ALJR 519; BC7300022Â (the absence of a cause of action must be very clear); Re Australian Property Custodian Holdings Ltd (in liq) (recs & mgrs apptd) [2012] NSWSC 679 atÂ [11]–[16]Â (poorly pleaded contract claim by third party beneficiary). Brimson v Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 937 at 944–5Â (this case contains a useful discussion of the alternative procedures available to a defendant who challenges the sufficiency of the plaintiff’s claim); Mathaman v Nabalco Pty Ltd (1969) 14 FLR 10Â ; Ruffıno v Grace Bros Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 732Â (claim against one concurrent tortfeasor where judgment obtained against another had already been satisfied); Shaloub Holdings Pty Ltd v Commonwealth Bank of Aust [2006] NSWSC 607; BC200604638 at [36]Â (insolvency alleged to result from cheque dishonoured by bank — hopeless claim).

Summary dismissal should be refused if the proceedings require determination of seriously disputed questions of fact: Spellson vÂ George (1992) 26 NSWLR 666; [1992] NSWCA 254; BC9203965Â (defence of consent to breach of trust). The likelihood of serious factual disputes may emerge from specifically pleaded allegations, the immediately identifiable evidence, or from evidence that may reasonably be anticipated. If material factual issues turn on evidence that is likely to be in the possession of the defendants, that circumstance can suffice to show that interlocutory dismissal of the proceedings is inappropriate. It may be reasonable to anticipate that material evidence favourable to the plaintiff’s claims will become available in the course of the proceedings — either as a result of interlocutory procedures for discovery and interrogatories (Wickstead vÂ Browne (1992) 30 NSWLR 1; [1992] NSWCA 272; BC9203970Â ); or evidence called by co-defendants or third parties: Wickstead vÂ Browne, above; cf Menzies vÂ Australian Iron & Steel Ltd (1952) 52 SR (NSW) 62; 69 WN (NSW) 68Â ; PtÂ 34 rrÂ 7(6) and 8(5); Peter Kent Development Pty Ltd vÂ ANZ Banking Group Ltd (SC(NSW), HuntÂ J, 6Â May 1980, unreported); Hogan vÂ Howard Finance Ltd [1987] ANZ ConvR 317; (1987) ASC 55-594; (1987) NSW ConvR 55-356; BC8701285Â .
Summary dismissal may be refused where the claim involves material dispute on a question of law: seeÂ [13.4.30].

The present rule’s power to dismiss a clearly unmeritorious claim has some similarity with the UCPR rÂ 13.1 power to grant summary judgment to a claimant. There is a close analogy between the “obviously untenable” criterion (relevant to dismissal) and the “triable issue” concept (relevant to summary judgment): see the discussion in [13.1.5] and [13.1.10] . However it is at least arguable that the dismissal power has a potentially wider scope: Cox vÂ Journeaux (NoÂ 2) (1935) 52 CLR 713 atÂ 720; 9 ALJR 127Â . In particular, UCPR rÂ 13.4(1)(b) refers to the absence of “reasonable cause of action”. The criterion of reasonableness introduces a permissive qualification that is not found in the terms of the summary judgment power: Spencer vÂ Commonwealth (2010) 241 CLR 118; 269 ALR 233; [2010] HCA 28; BC201006309 atÂ [49]–[60]Â (dealing with the absence of “reasonable prospects of success” (see also the Legal Profession ActÂ 2004 ssÂ 345–348 — restrictions on providing legal services where claims lack reasonable prospects of success). Although the power to dismiss proceedings on the basis that they disclose “no reasonable cause of action” requires a high degree of caution and certainty, the potentially permissive wording of UCPR rÂ 13.4(1)(b) applied against the background of the overriding purpose in CPA sÂ 56(1) and (2), encourages a practical judgment about the proceedings’ prospects of success. It suggests that the dismissal power conferred by the present rule is not confined to proceedings that are demonstrably certain to fail: Simmons vÂ Protective Commissioner of NSW (also known as NSW Trustee and Guardian) [2012] NSWSC 455; BC201202869 atÂ [52]–[64]Â ; McDonald vÂ Grech [2012] NSWSC 717; BC201204758 atÂ [32]–[33]Â .

An order may be made on an examination of the pleadings if that examination shows that the case is absolutely hopeless or that there is no possibility of the facts pleaded giving rise to a good cause of action: Dey v Victorian Railway Cmrs (1949) 78 CLR 62 at 90; [1949] ALR 333; BC4900050Â ; Goodson v Grierson [1908] 1 KB 761Â ; Tampion v Anderson [1973] VR 321 at 325Â . If the application is made on the pleadings and no evidence is adduced, the applicant for summary disposal must accept the truth of all allegations in the opposing pleading, including the ranges of meaning that the assertions of fact in that pleading are reasonably capable of bearing: Penthouse Publications Ltd v McWilliam (NSWCA, No 40465/90, 14 March 1991, unreported, BC9102223).

level.toc-caption: [13.4.25] Application to strike out pleadings, claims and contents of documents

p.text: Legislation cited in [13.4.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.28, r 4.15.

heading.title: Application to strike out pleadings, claims and contents of documents

p.text: The present rule applies to the proceedings generally, and to claims to relief in the proceedings. A party may apply under other rules to strike out pleadings, and also to strike out the contents of documents, on grounds similar to those stated in the present rule. Where the application relates to the contents of pleadings, r 14.28 applies. Where an order is sought that “matter” in a document (including a pleading) be “struck out” because it is frivolous, vexatious, etc, r 4.15 applies. See generally the notes accompanying those rules.

The present rule confers a similar power that applies generally to claims in the proceedings. It can apply, for example, to permit striking out a notice of contention, if the foreshadowed argument was virtually doomed to fail or if it would be plainly unjust in the circumstances for the respondent to be allowed to rely on it: HIA Insurance Services Pty Ltd t/as Home Owners Warranty v Kostas [2008] NSWCA 297; BC200810455 at [14]Â ; Hannover Life Re of Australasia Ltd v Dargan [2012] NSWCA 185; BC201204367 at [12]Â ff (judge invited to strike out a notice of contention would do so only if clearly persuaded that the — notice of contention not struck out).

Summary dismissal may be granted notwithstanding that extensive legal argument may be necessary to demonstrate the hopelessness of the claim: General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125 at 129; [1965] ALR 636; BC6400590Â ; Wilks v Haines (1991) Aust Torts Reports Â¶81-078 (claim for nervous shock inconsistent with the High Court decision in Jaensch v Coffey (1984) 155 CLR 549; 54 ALR 417Â ); Wickstead v Browne (1992) 30 NSWLR 1Â (whether trustee liable in negligence or only for breach of fiduciary duty); Commonwealth v Griffiths (2007) 245 ALR 172; [2007] NSWCA 370; BC200710981Â (defendants entitled to witness immunity — untenable duty of care claim). But in the exercise of the discretion, it is proper for courts of first instance to distinguish between claims that are merely novel and those that are plainly hopeless. If a claim raises an arguable point of law, summary judgment should generally not be ordered: Hospitals Contribution Fund of Australia Ltd v Hunt (1982) 44 ALR 365Â ; Eastern Petroleum Australia Ltd v Horseshoe Lights Gold Pty Ltd (1985) 9 ACLR 980Â ; Mills v Central Sydney Area Health Service [2002] NSWSC 728; BC200204850Â (arguable tort of spoilation of evidence).

level.toc-caption: [13.4.35] Defects curable by amendment of pleadings

heading.title: Defects curable by amendment of pleadings

p.text: An order to dismiss proceedings is not appropriate where the pleading is merely ill-expressed: Republic of Peru vÂ PeruvianGuano Co (1887) 36 Ch D 489; [1886–90] All ER Rep 368Â ; Wentworth vÂ Rogers (NoÂ 5) (1986) 6 NSWLR 534 atÂ 536; BC8601289Â . On an application for dismissal under this rule, a liberal construction should be given to the contentious pleading. In order to justify an order under the present rule the offending pleading must be beyond saving by legitimate amendment: Mutual Life & Citizens Assurance Co Ltd vÂ Evatt (1970) 122 CLR 628 atÂ 631; [1971] AC 793; [1971] ALR 235; BC7000440Â ; Penthouse Publications Ltd vÂ McWilliam (NSWCA, NoÂ 40465/90, 14Â March 1991, unreported, BC9102223); Brimson vÂ Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 937 atÂ 942Â . This consideration is particularly apt where the proceedings are complex or have been entered in the Specialist List. Frequent amendment is a familiar feature of complex litigation and an application for summary dismissal should not be determined on the basis that the plaintiff’s case will necessarily be confined to the matters that have been explicitly pleaded: Strong vÂ Simpson (SC(NSW), McLellandÂ J, 31Â July 1992, unreported, BC9201720); Penthouse Publications Ltd vÂ McWilliam, above. Even without formal amendment, the existing pleadings may permit a claimant to prove facts that would give rise to a good cause of action: Repacholi Aviation Pty Ltd vÂ Civil Aviation Safety Authority [2010] FCA 994; BC201006655 atÂ [38]Â . On the other hand it is obviously not appropriate to rely upon an issue in respect of which leave to amend has been refused: Ziras vÂ State Rail Authority (SC(NSW), AllenÂ J, NoÂ 16113/84, 6Â August 1991, unreported, BC9101706).

The court may receive evidence on any application under the rule and is not confined to dealing with the matter solely by reference to the pleadings: Wenlock v Moloney [1965] 2 All ER 871Â ; Howden v Truth & Sportsman Ltd (1937) 58 CLR 416 at 418Â ; Associated Securities Finance Ltd v Harrow Properties Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Lee J, 26 May 1977, unreported, BC7700002). Evidence may be necessary to explain the pleading (Rainy v Bravo (1872) LR 4 PC 287 at 296–7; Dougherty v Nationwide News Pty Ltd (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 146 at 149–51Â ), or to demonstrate by reference to other circumstances that the plaintiff’s case is hopeless (Willis v Earl Howe [1893] 2 Ch 545Â ; Peter Kent Development Pty Ltd v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (NSWSC, 6Â May 1980, unreported), or otherwise constitutes an abuse of process even though the pleading itself discloses no defect as to form: Burton v Shire of Bairnsdale (1908) 7 CLR 76; 14 ALR 529; [1908] HCA 57Â ; Lawrance v Lord Norreys (1890) 15 App Cas 210 at 219; [1886] All ER Rep 858 at 863Â .

Generally speaking, limitation issues should not be determined on an application for summary dismissal, or any other application made in advance of the hearing: Wardley Australia Ltd v Western Australia (1992) 175 CLR 514 at 532; 109 ALR 247; BC9202700Â ; Magman International Ltd v Westpac Banking Corporation Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 1; 104 ALR 575Â ; Kingsley Corporation Ltd v ANZ Banking Group (NoÂ 2) (NSWSC, 15 October 1997 unreported, BC9705146); McDonald vÂ Grech [2012] NSWSC 717; BC201204758Â atÂ [57] and [65] (uncertain timing of loss and arguable case of fraudulent concealment). But where a defendant has relied on a Limitation Act defence that clearly applies and has expired, the court may conclude that a statement of claim does not disclose a reasonable a cause of action under the present rule: Hillebrand v Penrith Council [2000] NSWSC 1058; BC200007069Â .

An order for summary dismissal of proceedings should not be made on the separate application of one of several co-defendants: Breheny v Cairncross [2002] NSWCA 69; BC200201114Â ; Ford v Nagle [2004] NSWCA 33; BC200400990Â ; Wickstead v Browne (1992) 30 NSWLR 1Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 13.5] r 13.5 Continuation of proceedings following partial dismissal (cf SCR Part 13, rule 6; DCR Part 11A, rule 4; LCR Part 10A, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Continuation of proceedings following partial dismissal (cf SCR Part 13, rule 6; DCR Part 11A, rule 4; LCR Part 10A, rule 4)

p.text: If, in any proceedings:
a party applies for an order for dismissal of proceedings, and
the proceedings are not wholly disposed of by dismissal,
the proceedings may be continued as regards any claim or part of a claim not disposed of by dismissal.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 13.6] r 13.6 Non-appearance by plaintiff (cf SCR Part 13, rule 5A)

leg:heading.title: Non-appearance by plaintiff (cf SCR Part 13, rule 5A)

p.text: If there is no attendance by or on behalf of a plaintiff at a hearing of which the plaintiff has had due notice, the court may adjourn the hearing to another date and direct that not less than 5 days before that date a notice of the adjournment be served on the plaintiff advising that the proceedings may be dismissed if there is no attendance by or on behalf of the plaintiff at the adjourned hearing.
If the plaintiff has been given notice in accordance with subrule (1) and there is no attendance by or on behalf of the plaintiff at the adjourned hearing, the court may dismiss the proceedings.
This rule does not restrict any other power of the court to dismiss proceedings.
[r 13.6 insrt Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[28], effective 15 August 2005]
